title: 1  Nextflow Code Clinic
text:
1.2 Preqrequisites

1.2.1 Familiarity with Nextflow
This workshop is intended to help improve writing of Nextflow workflows. As such we expect participants to be able to write basic Nextflow scripts, be able to script in a scripting language such as Bash/Python/R, and be familiar with their compute environment and job submission software.


1.2.2 Formatted code
Clean and readable code allows us to better understand what you’re attempting to do. Follow the formatting guidelines on Formatting Advice.


1.2.3 A test data set
When you’re prototying/developing a workflow, you want to keep writing code while you’re still in the flow of it. Having an aggressively subsampled data set means you’re not waiting long for tools to finish their job before you can move on to coding/fixing the next steps. Sometimes this is not possible, but making a best effort can help when you want to develop quickly, and allows you to construct a test suite for adding to the workflow without breaking it in the future.


1.2.4 Learning Outcomes

Learners will be able to formulate what they want their workflow to achieve ( publishable, portable, FAIR, etc).
Learners will be able to find resources to help them work towards a specific goal.
Learners will be able to identify what to target in their workflow to achieve a specific goal.
Learners will have made some changes to their workflow to achieve certain goal.

title: 17  Summary
text:
We hope this workshop has helped you to improve your Nextflow workflows.
If there is anything we can do better or you would like to see supported, please let us know by making an issue on our Github issues page.
If you’re in need of further help don’t forget to check-out the resources on the Nextflow support resources page.
Happy coding!
